review.title: Stance Classification of Social Media Users in Independence Movements
review.abstract: Social media and data mining are increasingly being used to analyse political and societal issues. Characterisation of users into socio-demographic groups is crucial to improve these analyses. Here we undertake the classification of social media users as supporting or opposing ongoing independence movements in their territories. Independence movements occur in territories whose citizens have conflicting national identities; users with opposing national identities will then support or oppose the sense of being part of an independent nation that differs from the officially recognised country. We describe a methodology that relies on users' self-reported location to build datasets for three territories -- Catalonia, the Basque Country and Scotland -- and we test language-independent classifiers using four types of features. We show the effectiveness of the approach to build large annotated datasets, and the ability to achieve accurate, language-independent classification performances ranging from 85% to 97% for the three territories under study.

sections.heading: 1 INTRODUCTION
sections.text: SOCIAL media are becoming an increasingly important source of data mining applications, including exploratory research used as a means of analysing political and social issues or information and news gathering. However, one of the problems with social media is the limited availability of socio-demographic details of users that would allow the development of data mining tools that take into account the many different realities in society. Attempting to mitigate this problem shows that an increasing number of research in the field of natural language processing and data mining deals with the automated return of socio-demographic characteristics such as age and gender, country of origin [1] or political orientation [2]. Following this line of research, we describe and evaluate a data collection and classification methodology that allows two groups of social media users to identify themselves in areas with active independence movements: those who support independence, and those who oppose it (anti-independence nationality) as different parts of an independent Catalan population are motivated by national identity movements.

sections.heading: 7 DISCUSSION
sections.text: The methodology described here enabled us to collect large sets of data to tackle the unexplored task of determining Twitter users "attitudes towards independence movements, as well as a classifier that can automatically determine this attitude. Our methodology and classifiers have been tested in three territories with persistent independence movements and conflicting national identities: Scotland, Catalonia and the Basque Country. Our classification experiments show encouraging results with high performance values ranging from 85% to 97% accuracy using a maximum entropy classifier that exploits each user's social network. In addition, and in a realistic scenario, the classifier trained by users whose self-reported location field reveals their national identity can be applied to other users in that particular territory. Classification of users by national identity can then be used for further analysis of social and political issues, as well as for targeting the user's own interests.
